answers: power spectrum of the cosmic microwave background/CMB
parts: Name this graph, whose x-axis plots the angular scale and the multipole moment. The position of the first peak is an indication of the curvature of the universe.

The cosmic microwave background is predicted by this theory, which states that the universe rapidly expanded from an initial singularity. Cosmic inflation solved the flatness, horizon, and monopole problems from this theory.
Cosmic inflation predicts that the majority of the matter-energy density of the universe is comprised of this substance, which is responsible for accelerating the expansion of the universe.

Name this mystical tradition of contemplative prayer championed by Gregory Palamas. Supporters of this controversial practice generally associated with John VI Kantakouzenos in the Byzantine civil war of the 1340s.

During the civil war, the radical anti-noble Zealots took control of this populous Greek city in support of John V. St. Ambrose rebuked Theodosius I for massacring thousands of residents of this city with Gothic troops.

Kantakouzenos granted a fort on this peninsula to the Ottomans in exchange for their help in Thrace, though they seized the whole peninsula two years later. ANZAC day commemorates a costly campaign on this Dardanelles peninsula during World War I.
Name this Ojibwe American author of the stories “Saint Marie” and “The Red Convertible,” both of which were also published as part of her first novel, Love Medicine.

Most of Erdrich’s novels are set in one of these settlements in North Dakota, inhabited by the Chippewa. Sherman Alexie’s novel about an Indian rock band is titled for the “Blues” of one of these places.

This Arapaho and Cheyenne author explored the lives of Native Americans dealing with life in the city away from the reservation and traditions in his 2018 debut novel There, There, which was a finalist for the Pulitzer.

answers: Behistun inscription [or the Behistun rock; accept Bisotun or Bistun or Bisutun in place of "Behistun"]
parts: Name this rock relief carving in western Iran. In addition to the depicted scene, this site—unrelated to the Rosetta Stone—also includes cuneiform (“kyoo-NAY-if-orm”) writing in three different languages, which was an essential tool in deciphering that writing system.

The Behistun inscription is often compared to the Rosetta Stone, whose translation was a race between Jean-François Champollion and this British polymath. He made the first breakthroughs in the Demotic translation.
The inscriptions on the Cascajal block may represent an early writing system of this civilization; this early Mesoamerican civilization also created numerous colossal heads carved from boulders.
Name this protein consisting of 3 heavy and 3 light chains which clusters in namesake coated pits to induce the formation of vesicles in endocytosis.
LDL receptors localize to clathrin coated pits; LDL is misleadingly called the “bad” kind of this lipid, which has 27 carbons and is used to maintain membrane fluidity.

Another example of receptor-mediated endocytosis occurs when this iron-binding plasma glycoprotein binds to its receptor. The saturation percentage of this protein is low in patients with iron-deficiency anemia.

answers: Russian Futurism [or Cubo-Futurism; or Italian Futurism]
in the corner of the room
parts: Name this artistic movement that informed the set design for the opera Victory over the Sun. In another country, a movement of this name glorified the beauty of war and the motion of a “roaring motor car.”
A painting depicting The Knife Grinder was created during the Cubo-Futurist phase of this Russian artist of The Black Square, the founder of Suprematism.

In reference to medieval artistic tradition, Malevich’s Black Square was exhibited in this way at the 0,10 Exhibition. Vladimir Tatlin created Constructivist Counter-Reliefs meant to be exhibited in this way.
Name this character, who describes Isidora, Diomira, and other locations to the emperor of the Tartars.
Marco Polo recounts his travels to Kublai Khan in Invisible Cities, a book by this author who also wrote If on a a winter’s night a traveler.

Calvino patterned section titles in Invisible Cities after a sine wave, signifying his membership in this literary group including Raymond Queneau known for their strict mathematical writing constraints.

answers: José de la Cruz Porfirio Díaz Mori
parts: US Ambassador Dwight Morrow was known as the “ham and eggs diplomat” for his breakfast meetings with this Mexican president known as “Jefe Máximo,” whose anti-Catholic policies sparked the Cristero War in 1926.

This other Mexican president used the slogan “bread or the stick” to suppress political agitation. The technocratic científicos advised this dictator until his deposition at the beginning of the Mexican Revolution.
The term “coffee and milk politics” described the domination of this country’s Old Republic government by elites of the coffee and dairy industries centered in Minas Gerais and São Paulo.
Identify this last of the yugas, during which Kalki will emerge as the final avatar of Vishnu. It is generally characterized as an apocalyptic time resulting in the breakdown of morals.
Kalki is often depicted riding on a white one of these animals while carrying a flaming sword. Bellerophon attempted to ride one of these animals with wings named Pegasus up to Mount Olympus

During the Kali Yuga, the horse sacrifice ritual of Ashvamedha was banned; that wouldn’t have boded well with this son of Shakuntala and Dushyanta who, according to Kalidasa, performed the ritual upwards of 1800 times.

answers: Saint Eric [or Eric IX; or Eric the Holy; or Eric the Lawgiver; prompt on Eric]
parts: Name this country conquered and colonized by Sweden in three crusades against tribes like the Tavastians and Karelians. The Soviet Union took Vyborg from this country during the Winter War.
This Swedish king led the mythical First Swedish Crusade along with the English Bishop Henry, though historical evidence documents that Christianization had already begun among the Finns.
Saint Eric is buried in the cathedral of this Swedish city, whose Archbishop is the primate of Sweden. Adam of Bremen described a large temple in this city dedicated to the pagan Norse pantheon.
Name this Japanese-German author of a book in which the matriarch is a circus performer who moves from Moscow to Canada, Memoirs of a Polar Bear.
In an essay about this poet of “Death Fugue,” Tawada writes about his use of seven words that are translated with the Japanese radical for “gate” in “Seven Roses Later.”

Yoko Tawada and Paul Celan are both exophonic writers, or writers who do not write in their native language. This author of The Unbearable Lightness of Being is also exophonic, writing in French instead of his native Czech.

answers: Samuel Vimes [accept either underlined part; accept the Duke of Ankh]
Sir Terry Pratchett (the unnamed novel is Good Omens, co-written with Neil Gaiman)
parts: Name this watchman, a former alcoholic-turned-cigar smoker who obsesses over reading Where’s My Cow? to his son every night. His many titles include “Ambassador” and “Blackboard Monitor.”
Sam Vimes’ wife, Lady Sybil, runs a sanctuary for the “swamp” versions of these creatures. One of these creatures named Smaug serves as the main villain of The Hobbit.

Vimes was created by this author, who set books like Guards! Guards! in Ankh-Morpork. This author, who passed away in 2015, wrote about an angel and demon who try to use a set of “nice and accurate prophecies” to avert the apocalypse.

answers: recite surah al-Fatihah [accept descriptions or translations of al-Fatihah like the Opening or the first surah of the Quran]
parts: Name this action performed at the beginning of each ruk’a. According to al-Bukhari, a man who was bitten by a scorpion was healed after another man performed this action.
Multiple ruk’a comprise this action called salat, which Muslims perform 5 times a day.
A somewhat controversial form of bid’ah or innovation is reciting al-Fatihah during one of these events, typically facilitated by the wali mujbir.

answers: Lucinda Leplastrier (from Oscar and Lucinda by Peter Carey)
parts: Name this Miles Franklin novel about Sybylla Melvin, who refuses to marry Harold Beecham, written by the author of All that Swagger. It was followed by a sequel in which its title concept "goes Bung."
This other female Australian character is an heiress who bets a man that he cannot bring a glass church across the Outback.
In My Brilliant Career, Sybylla is forced to work in this position for the extremely uncultured M'Swat family. Jane Eyre holds this position for the daughter of Mr. Rochester.
Name this piece, which begins with five bars of solemn percussion and silence before the three trumpets enter in unison playing the heroic main theme, which sounds as an ascending F - B-flat – F.
This composer of Fanfare for the Common Man confessed that he preferred his own version to the cover by Emerson, Lake and Palmer. He also composed Appalachian Spring.

This contemporary composer responded to Copland’s piece with Fanfare for the Uncommon Woman, which uses the same instrumentation. She co-founded the Da Capo Chamber Players and won three Grammys for her 2008 piece Made in America.
Identify this essay that outlines options that may be “living or dead, forced or avoidable, [or] momentous or trivial.”
“The Will to Believe” was written by this American philosopher, whose Gifford Lectures were compiled into The Varieties of Religious Experience.

In another essay on the “Dilemma of” this concept, James proposed subjectivism as one method of escaping it. Galen Strawson’s paper “The Impossibility of Moral Responsibility” holds that responsibility is impossible regardless of whether this position is true or not.

Name this quantity symbolized mu which describes the response of a material to a magnetic field. For free space, it equals 4 pi times 10 to the negative 7 Henries per meter - until recently, when it was redefined.

A plot of the B-field versus the H-field is a straight line for most materials, but for ferromagnets it is one of these shapes, which depends on the history of the magnetization. Magnetic saturation occurs at the endpoints of these shapes.
The bound current density inside a magnetized object is given by this formula in terms of the magnetization M. You may assume SI units and ignore conversion factors such as the speed of light.

answers: bones [or Bone Wars; or fossils; accept equivalents relating to dinosaur skeletons]
parts: Name this Yale scientist who gave the genus Triceratops its name. This man spent his career furiously competing with University of Pennsylvania professor Edward Drinker Cope.

Cope and Marsh engaged in “wars” over these objects sought after by paleontologists. Their rivalry began when Marsh pointed out to Cope that he had incorrectly arranged these objects in an elasmosaurus.
After the U.S. government opened this range to gold mining, Marsh promised Red Cloud to lobby on his behalf in Washington in return for fossils.

answers: white balance [accept gray balance or neutral balance or color balance]
parts: Give this term for the adjustments made to the color intensities in a photo to compensate for the color temperature of the surrounding light, so that the image is reproduced with the correct hues.

This company developed the first successful color tri-pack film, a portmanteau of its own name and the word “chrome.” This company was founded by George Eastman and its name became an adjective for “moments” worthy of capture.

Eliot Porter and Philip Hyde helped establish color photography as a fine art through their work for this organization and its lobbying efforts. This group published books such as Wilderness is the Preservation of the World featuring Porter’s work and Island in Time: The Point Reyes Peninsula featuring Hyde’s.
Name this series of elements above the actinides on the periodic table. They have a partially filled 4f orbitals.
The unstable lanthanide promethium decays mostly to this element. This element is used to dope yttrium aluminum garnet in a common type of laser.
Lanthanides are often used as part of these reagents in NMR, which produce different signals when they react with different stereoisomers of a given compound.
